description: From Middle English curious, from Old French curius, from Latin cūriōsus. The English word is cognate with Italian curioso, Occitan curios, Portuguese curioso, and Spanish curioso.

adjectives.description: curious (comparative more curious or curiouser, superlative most curious or curiousest)

entries.meaning: Tending to ask questions, or to want to explore or investigate; inquisitive; (with a negative connotation) nosy, prying.
examples: Synonyms: enquiring, inquiring; (obsolete) exquisitive; investigative; (rare) peery
Young children are naturally curious about the world and everything in it.

entries.meaning: Leading one to ask questions about; somewhat odd, out of the ordinary, or unusual.
examples: The platypus is a curious creature, with fur like a mammal and a beak like a bird.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Careful, fastidious, particular; (specifically) demanding a high standard of excellence, difficult to satisfy.
(obsolete) Carefully or artfully constructed; made with great elegance or skill.
(chemistry, rare) Containing or pertaining to trivalent curium.
